docs.lead_paragraph: WE were looking for a place we could afford,'' said Linda DiBrita. A 30-year-old who works for a bank and plans to start a business as a quilt maker, she and her husband, Anthony, a lawyer, had been renting in a brownstone in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn last year when they decided they needed more space. They found a one-bedroom apartment on the ninth floor of Citylights, the new 42-story co-op in Long Island City, the first building in the 74-acre Queens West development along the East River. They paid only $20,000 and took on carrying costs of $1,090 a month, 60 percent of it tax deductible.

headline.main: Queens West Pioneers Are Getting Company

docs.abstract: Next phase of development to commence in Queens West complex in Long Island City, which has dramatic views of Manhattan across East River; photos of completed building, Citylights; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS a concept, art for art's sake seems to have been superseded by art that illustrates or preaches. Whether this is the will of artists or art educators is a moot point, but there is no doubt that, like the squeaky wheel, the show promoting a blameless cause is the one most likely to get the Federal, state or corporate grease. A current example is ''Say Ahh! Examining America's Health,'' which has nothing to do with art but is nonetheless on view at the Hudson River Museum here. A combined effort by the Strong Museum of Rochester, the Health Museum of Cleveland and the College of Physicians of Philadelphia, this World's Fair-type spectacle has many sponsors, including Johnson & Johnson Clinical Diagnostics, the New York Council for the Humanities, Blue Cross and Blue Shield in the Rochester area and, during its Westchester stint, the Bayer Corporation of Tarrytown.
docs.abstract: Vivien Raynor reviews exhibition on 150 years of American medicine at Hudson River Museum in Yonkers; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MARKETS Higher Still and Higher Ignoring earnings warnings from several companies -- most recently, Sunbeam and Rockwell International -- investors kept bidding up stock prices, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to five consecutive records. The Dow ended the week at 8,906.43, up 303.91. Behind the market's gains are low interest rates, low inflation and bullish analysts. Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, raised her 1998 Dow target to 9,300. . . . The boards of the National Association of Securities Dealers, and the American Stock Exchange backed merger plans. Frank G. Zarb, chairman of the N.A.S.D., said a market of markets would result. The N.A.S.D. promised to invest at least $110 million in technology and other improvements if it takes control of the Amex.

docs.lead_paragraph: SINCE the start of the 1970's, an obscure group of economists and health specialists had been flogging notions of universal medical care to the deaf ears of legislators and Presidents. The group's organizers, Paul M. Ellwood, formerly a pediatric neurologist in Minneapolis, and Alain C. Enthoven, a health economist at Stanford University, had a theory about expanding the cost-efficient practices of managed care into a vast system that would cover all Americans.

headline.main: The Nation; Looking Back At Jackson Hole

docs.abstract: Members of Jackson Hole Group comment on the good and bad produced by growth of managed health care in four years since defeat of Pres Clinton's plan for universal health care; note that Clinton's plan was based on their of ideas for having Government direct competition among health care plans with the object of driving down health care costs and saving enough money to extend insurance to those not covered, whereas that growth of managed care in last four years has been due to market forces; say that managed care has succeeded in slowing inflation in health costs but that percentage of Americans under 65 without health insurance has rise to 17.7 percent from 17 percent in 1992; say those covered by managed care are probably healthier than they were under fee-for-service plans because they enjoy better preventive care; Dr Paul M Ellwood and Alain C Enthoven comment; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are two commonly held beliefs about today's New York. No. 1: Things are good. No. 2: Everyone agrees about No. 1. The prevailing wisdom holds that the city is basking in a glorious period of renewal, evidenced and enhanced by a robust economy, a revitalized cultural scene and surging self-confidence.

headline.main: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

docs.abstract: Upbeat news that New York City is basking in a glorious period of economic and social renewal is seen by some resident skeptics as largely a creation of high-powered civic boosters who have a major stake in how the city is percieved; and, the critics say, the city's refurbished image has little to do with the lives of most New Yorkers; sampling of comments suggesting a reality check is due; drawings; photo (L)
docs.snippet: THERE are two commonly held beliefs about today's New York. No. 1: Things are good. No. 2: Everyone agrees about No. 1.     The prevailing wisdom holds that the city is basking in a glorious period of renewal, evidenced and enhanced by a robust...

byline.original: By JESSE McKINLEY and ANDREW JACOBS

docs.lead_paragraph: The state of California is considering circumventing its long-entrenched health maintenance organizations and contracting directly with groups of physicians and hospitals for medical care for its 1,024,000 employees, a state health benefits official told a weekend meeting of physicians and health system executives. Margaret T. Stanley, health benefits administrator for the big California Public Employees' Retirement System, said on Friday that the agency was considering terminating the H.M.O.'s rights to unilaterally raise the prices they charge for prescriptions. And she told doctors her agency wants to pay higher fees to those who provide the best quality care.

headline.main: California Agency Ponders Bypassing Health Groups

docs.abstract: State of California is considering circumventing its long-entrenched health maintenance organizations and contracting directly with groups of physicians and hospitals for medical care for its 1,024,000 employees; Margaret T Stanley, health benefits administrator for California Public Employees' Retirement System, says recent mergers and consolidation means that state's big for-profit HMO's often have their eyes on Wall Street rather than on patients (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DARRIN SCHOEN'S friends call him ''the Specialist.'' A 20-something construction manager, he can fix anything: tune cars, clear drains, repair masonry. When it comes to fixing his finances, though, Mr. Schoen doesn't know the stock market from a circular saw. He owns no securities. He has never put money anywhere except in a checking account. And recently, when Maury Zanoff, a financial planner and a friend of Mr. Schoen, gingerly said, ''I don't know how much you know about mutual funds . . .,'' Mr. Schoen quickly put his index finger and thumb together to signal ''zero.''
docs.abstract: Fresh Start, periodic series that looks at crossroads of personal finance, focuses on Darrin Schoen, 27-year-old handyman who, until recently, had money only in his checking account; Schoen has no benefits or pension and slim after-tax resources from his paycheck; Maury Zanoff, financial planner and friend of Schoen, laid out plan to improve his financial future, which leaves Schoen $1 after investments are made and bills paid; Schoen says he is determined to adopt Zanoff's plan; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR a quarter-century, the message from the job market has been loud and clear. Avoid traditional blue-collar work. Go to college. Scramble for a foothold in the service industry elite, where unions and seniority mean little and adaptability is the most prized talent. If you are really ambitious and prepared to risk your life savings, start your own business. But don't try telling that to Lynn Hummel, a former bank clerk who tripled her earnings by becoming a longshoreman in Los Angeles. Or to Eugene Vasser, who says he makes ''substantially more than $100,000 a year'' working for a welding equipment maker in Cleveland that pays according to individual productivity. Or to Herman Aguirre, a Colombian immigrant who worked his way up from janitor to master jewelry maker in a New York City loft factory and now commands a six-figure income.
docs.abstract: While median annual earnings of male high school graduates in 1995 was just $29,000, down by one-fifth since 1976--after taking inflation into account--there are growing number of blue-collar workers whose earnings defy trend; for these workers, success turns on working longer and harder, for others high pay comes with highly valued skills not taught in college, while for still others it is often a matter of joining one of the small powerful unions that move semiskilled workers into upper-middle class; profiles of some of these highly-paid workers, some of whom have earnings that exceed $100,000 a year; photos; chart on median weekly earnings for selected occupations in 1996 (L)
